awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Carbon Based, Low-Density Radiation Shielding Material
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the improved safety and reduced cost of managing nuclear waste.  Current lightweight radiation shielding materials lack the required temperature stability.  New radiation shielding materials with better properties are needed to protect the health of biological, electrical, and structural systems in radioactive environments.  Radiation shielding improvements in the nuclear industry could result in upwards of one billion dollars in savings annually and result in lower electricity costs.  Commercialization of these advanced materials can also minimize the effects of disasters like Fukushima and reduce the costs of clean-up efforts.  Lightweight radiation shielding materials are also needed in airplanes and satellites to protect workers and electronic systems from cosmic radiation and for medical personnel working with radiation related treatments. 
 
This I-Corps project is based on an innovative lightweight radiation shielding material that withstands operating temperatures nearly double those of commercially available products.  It has been demonstrated that the addition of carbon-based particles can more quickly move heat away from radioactive waste; this enables safer disposal options for the nuclear waste.  Additional technical merit lies in the fabrication process that has been developed to reduce the weight and size of the material.  It also enables the technology to be cost competitive with existing products while providing better shielding properties. The I-Corps investigation will determine the commercial potential for this material.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Throughout the seven weeks of the NSF I-Corps program, Neutroelectric interviewed over 142 experts in industries that rely on radiation shielding to protect people and equipment.  The need for a high-temperature, lightweight neutron-shielding material was validated for several key markets in the nuclear industry, namely, for in-containment reactor shielding and for high-heat-load spent-fuel transport casks.  Reactor vendors and other Tier 1 suppliers form the customer base for reactor design. Spent-fuel transport cask supply companies form the customer base for the transport cask market. In both markets, the industry has experienced component failures and design limitations due to the temperature limitations of the currently available lightweight neutron-shielding materials. Several customers stated that their need for a higher-temperature material was immediate. This target market is estimated to be worth $20–40M over the next decade and was deemed sufficient to support a start-up to sell our flagship product, NE-300. With this result, a “GO” decision was made to commercialize NE-300.  The team has continued using the Business Model Canvas to develop our business plan and, using the insight gained through the I-Corps program, has competed and won multiple Business Plan and Business Pitch competitions collecting $50,000 in unrestricted funds.

The proposal team continued the customer discovery process after the six-week I-Corps program was completed. Several companies were revisited which provided opportunity for further discussions regarding the use of NE-300 in reactors and transport-cask design. As a result of this process, an issue was identified with one of the key material properties, the coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE). It was found that the CTE for NE-300 is five times higher than that of the current low-temperature materials; this is outside of the acceptable range for our target applications.  The differential expansion between the absorbing material and the metal containments in which it resides should be small to keep the shield from expanding and expelling from its containment. This would be further exacerbated by the 100oC increase in the application temperature that produces additional expansion over the lower-temperature materials. All other key properties of NE-300 exceed the performance of those in current use. Thus, in the post I-CORP program customer discovery process, the need to reduce the CTE for NE-300 has become a mandate for successful commercialization and must be addressed.

A broader impact of our technology is in improving the safety and reducing the cost of low-carbon electricity.  Nuclear power is the United States’ largest source of reliable low-carbon electricity. Unfortunately, nuclear power use is limited due to public perception about the risks associated with nuclear waste management. Advancements in materials for the nuclear fuel cycle are very important to ensure the safe and economical operation of existing nuclear power plants, generation IV reactors, small modular reactors, and decommissioning activities. Among the advancements in materials that address issues with nuclear reactors and nuclear waste management are new, low-density neutron-shielding materials such as NE-300. Beyond nuclear fuel management, low-density radiation shielding materials are needed to protect critical components in airplanes, satellites, and robotic systems that inspect equipment at nuclear power plants and nuclear submarines. Low-density neutron-shielding materials are also used to protect workers, such as those working with neutron radiation in national labs and physicians and staff working with medical equipment during neutron radiography or radiation therapy.
